title: 108_s2932
content: The Act titled the "Mark O. Hatfield-Elizabeth Furse Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Act of 2004" honors Senator Hatfield and Congresswoman Furse for their work in strengthening tribal self-governance and advocating for Native American rights. The Act establishes programs to promote excellence in tribal government. The Act defines key terms such as Board, eligible individual, Foundation, Fund, Institute, institution of higher education, and State. The Act defines key terms such as Board, eligible individual, Foundation, Fund, Institute, institution of higher education, and State, which includes various entities like States, the District of Columbia, and U.S. territories. Establishment of the Mark O. Hatfield-Elizabeth Furse Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Foundation. The Mark O. Hatfield-Elizabeth Furse Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Foundation is established as an independent entity in the Executive branch. It is supervised by a Board of Trustees consisting of 12 members appointed by the President and Senate, with recommendations from congressional leaders. The Board of Trustees for the Mark O. Hatfield-Elizabeth Furse Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Foundation consists of 12 members appointed by the President and Senate, including tribal leaders, the Secretary of the Interior, the Secretary of Education, and the president of Portland State University. Trustees serve a 6-year term. The term of a member of the Board shall be 6 years, with exceptions for initial trustees appointed by the President for varying terms. Vacancy appointments serve for the remainder of the term. The Foundation's trustee appointed to fill a vacancy serves for the remainder of the term and is appointed in the same manner as the original appointment. Trustees serve without pay but are reimbursed for necessary expenses. The Foundation is located in Portland, Oregon. An Executive Director, appointed by the Board, serves as the chief executive officer and carries out the Foundation's functions under the Board's supervision. The Executive Director, under the supervision of the Board, performs functions as prescribed by the Act and is compensated at the rate specified for an employee in level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Foundation's purposes include training tribal council members, promoting understanding of tribal self-government, addressing critical tribal issues, conducting governance research, and providing educational outreach. The Foundation, in consultation with the Institute, may conduct programs, activities, and services to carry out its purposes. This includes awarding scholarships, fellowships, internships, and grants, as well as organizing national competitions to select recipients. Eligible individuals can receive scholarships, fellowships, internships, and grants for study in fields related to tribal governance. The Foundation awards scholarships, fellowships, internships, and grants for study in tribal governance fields. Recipients are named "Elizabeth Furse Scholars." Scholarships are given to outstanding undergraduate students pursuing careers in tribal governance or tribal public policy. Eligible individuals must maintain proficiency, devote full time to study, and not engage in other gainful employment without Foundation approval. The Foundation may require reports and certificates from scholarship recipients to ensure satisfactory progress in study or research. Fellowships are awarded to outstanding graduate students in fields related to tribal governance. The Foundation awards scholarships to graduate students in tribal governance-related fields, including Native American and Alaska Native students. It also provides internships and grants for research on tribal governance and public policy issues. The Foundation awards scholarships and grants for research on tribal governance and public policy issues. It conducts tribal governance policy research, research on Native American and Alaska Native tribal public policy issues, and invites visiting policymakers to share practical experiences. The Foundation assists in developing a program for tribal governance research at the Institute and determines program priorities and fund allocations. The Foundation awards scholarships and grants for research on tribal governance and public policy issues. It conducts research on Native American and Alaska Native tribal public policy issues and invites policymakers to share practical experiences. Not less than 20 percent of funds are allocated to the Institute for specific purposes with matching share requirements, and not more than 15 percent is used for salaries and administrative purposes. SEC. 7. ESTABLISHMENT OF MARK O. HATFIELD-ELIZABETH FURSE SCHOLARSHIP AND EXCELLENCE IN TRIBAL GOVERNANCE TRUST FUND. A trust fund named the "Mark O. Hatfield-Elizabeth Furse Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Trust Fund" is established in the Treasury of the United States, to be managed by the Foundation and invested in public debt securities. SEC. 8. EXPENDITURES AND AUDIT OF TRUST FUND. SEC. 8. EXPENDITURES AND AUDIT OF TRUST FUND. The Foundation will use interest and earnings from the Fund as determined by the Board to carry out the Act. The Government Accountability Office may audit the Foundation and Institute activities under this Act with access to all relevant documents. The Foundation can appoint personnel, procure services of experts, promulgate regulations, and accept gifts to support its work. The Foundation can accept gifts, use voluntary personnel, enter contracts, and make necessary expenditures to support its work. Authorization of appropriations: $50,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated to the Fund.
